title: How to build a fictional world - Kate Messner

multiple-choice.question: What do authors of science fiction and fantasy do when creating fictional worlds?

options.label: A
options.text: They make up random rules and ignore them.

options.label: B
options.text: They literally build worlds by creating rules, maps, lineages, languages, cultures, universes, and more.

options.label: C
options.text: They only focus on the main characters and ignore the rest of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: They never think about the world they are creating.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the first step in building a fictional world?

options.label: A
options.text: Create a list of characters.

options.label: B
options.text: Brainstorm answers to questions that draw out the details of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: Write a detailed timeline of the world's history.

options.label: D
options.text: Decide on the setting and time period.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest is the key to creating a believable and comprehensible fictional world?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignoring the rules of the world and making up new ones.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a world that is completely opposite of the real world.

options.label: C
options.text: Operating consistently within a spectrum of physical and societal rules.

options.label: D
options.text: Making the world as complex and confusing as possible.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author recommend doing to get started writing a novel?

options.label: A
options.text: Dream up an entire world and characters from scratch.

options.label: B
options.text: Start writing the first chapter without any planning.

options.label: C
options.text: Begin with a basic place and time, and then brainstorm answers to questions that draw out the details of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Research and read extensively about the topic before starting to write.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest is the most important aspect of building a fictional world?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating a detailed timeline of the world's history.

options.label: B
options.text: Developing complex and realistic characters.

options.label: C
options.text: Thinking about day-to-day life in the world, including the weather, food, and relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: Making the world as simple and straightforward as possible.

title: How sugar affects the brain - Nicole Avena

multiple-choice.question: What happens in the brain when sugar hits the tongue?

options.label: A
options.text: It activates the brain's reward system immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: It sends a signal to the stomach to digest the sugar.

options.label: C
options.text: It activates the sweet-taste receptors, which send a signal up to the brain stem.

options.label: D
options.text: It triggers a release of insulin to deal with the extra sugar.

multiple-choice.question: What is the major currency of the brain's reward system?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucose

options.label: B
options.text: Dopamine

options.label: C
options.text: Sugar

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin

multiple-choice.question: Why does the dopamine response level out when a food becomes boring?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the brain is no longer interested in the food.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the brain has adapted to the food and no longer finds it rewarding.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain is not paying attention to new or different tastes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the brain is no longer hungry.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when sugar is consumed too much and too often?

options.label: A
options.text: The dopamine response levels out.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's reward system is no longer activated.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain becomes desensitized to sugar.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain goes into overdrive, leading to addictive effects.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it that sugar-rich foods can be addictive?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are low in nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they activate the brain's reward system, causing a release of dopamine.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are bad for your health.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The death of the universe

multiple-choice.question: According to the Theory of General Relativity, what are the three possible shapes of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Positively curved, negatively curved, or flat

options.label: B
options.text: Spherical, flat, or open

options.label: C
options.text: Closed, open, or negatively curved

options.label: D
options.text: Flat, negatively curved, or positively curved

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the total energy of the universe is made up of ordinary or baryonic matter?
What is dark matter, and how is it detected?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark matter is a type of ordinary matter that reflects light, and it is detected through its gravitational interaction with other objects.

options.label: B
options.text: Dark matter is only weakly interacting with light, and it is detected through its gravitational interaction with other objects.

options.label: C
options.text: Dark matter is a type of anti-matter that interacts with light, and it is detected through its reflection.

options.label: D
options.text: Dark matter is a type of energy that does not interact with light, and it is detected through its absence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the leading idea for dark energy, and how does it affect the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The leading idea for dark energy is that it is a type of matter that expands as the volume of space increases, and it causes the universe to contract.

options.label: B
options.text: The leading idea for dark energy is that it is a cosmological constant that expands as the volume of space increases, and it causes the universe to expand faster and faster.

options.label: C
options.text: The leading idea for dark energy is that it is a type of energy that does not interact with matter, and it causes the universe to remain static.

options.label: D
options.text: The leading idea for dark energy is that it is a type of matter that does not interact with light, and it causes the universe to contract.

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted fate of the universe in the distant future?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe will remain static and continue to form new stars and planets.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe will contract and eventually collapse into a singularity.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe will continue to expand and eventually become cold and empty, leading to the heat death of the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe will remain in a state of constant acceleration, but will eventually become static.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the low temperature of the water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the unique interaction between molecules in water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the high pressure of the water.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the hydrogen bonds in water molecules when the temperature is above 4 degrees Celsius?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They form and break quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: They form and break in a random manner.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not form at all.

options.label: B
options.text: The oceans would become colder.

options.label: C
options.text: The oceans would remain the same.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How atoms bond - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What type of bond forms when one atom is really strong and pulls one or more electrons off another atom?

options.label: B
options.text: Ionic bond

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen bond

options.label: D
options.text: Electrostatic bond

options.label: A
options.text: Ionic bond

options.label: B
options.text: Covalent bond

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen bond

options.label: D
options.text: Electrostatic bond

options.label: D
options.text: Its electrons are arranged in a specific pattern.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Atom

title: Kabuki: The people's dramatic art - Amanda Mattes

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "Kabuki"?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Japanese verb "kabuku", meaning "to dance"

options.label: B
options.text: From the Japanese verb "kabuku", meaning "out of the ordinary or bizarre"

options.label: C
options.text: From the Japanese word "keshou", meaning "makeup"

options.label: D
options.text: From the Japanese word "Onna-Kabuki", meaning "female dance"

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with pioneering Kabuki as Japan's first dramatic performance form?

options.label: A
options.text: Izumo no Okuni, a shrine maiden

options.label: B
options.text: Claude Monet, a European artist

options.label: C
options.text: Vincent van Gogh, a European artist

options.label: D
options.text: Tetsuji Takechi, a Japanese director

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the ban on Onna-Kabuki by the Tokugawa shogunate in 1629?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to the risqué nature of the performances

options.label: B
options.text: Due to the influence of Bunraku on Kabuki

options.label: C
options.text: Due to the use of elaborate costumes and makeup

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the focus on historical events and everyday life

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the influence of Bunraku on Kabuki?

options.label: A
options.text: Kabuki became a more spontaneous and one-act dance

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki became a more structured and five-act play

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki became a more focused on folk tales

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki became a more focused on upper-class dance theater

options.label: A
options.text: Japan continued to practice isolation from other countries

options.label: B
options.text: Japan began to adopt Western art forms and influences

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki suffered in popularity and was eventually banned

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki underwent much change and experimentation to adapt to the new modern era

title: Light waves, visible and invisible

multiple-choice.question: What is the range of light that our eyes are sensitive to?

options.label: A
options.text: Low-energy light, high-energy light, and everything in between

options.label: B
options.text: Only light with a very small range in energy, which we call visible light

options.label: C
options.text: All types of light, including radio waves and x-rays

options.label: D
options.text: Only light that is red and invisible to the human eye

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between radio waves and x-rays?

options.label: A
options.text: Radio waves have high energy, while x-rays have low energy

options.label: B
options.text: Radio waves have long wavelengths, while x-rays have short wavelengths

options.label: C
options.text: Radio waves are visible to the human eye, while x-rays are not

options.label: D
options.text: Radio waves are used for heating food, while x-rays are used for medical imaging

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we see light that has an energy our retina can't measure?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's too short wavelength or high energy

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's too long wavelength or low energy

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's invisible to the human eye

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not part of the visible spectrum

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of special detectors that can measure light outside of the visible range?

options.label: A
options.text: To see the light that is there, even though we can't see it ourselves

options.label: B
options.text: To make the light visible to the human eye

options.label: C
options.text: To block out the light that is not visible to the human eye

options.label: D
options.text: To change the wavelength of the light

multiple-choice.question: Why is it necessary to use special telescopes to see the universe in its full spectrum?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the universe is too far away

options.label: B
options.text: Because the universe is too big

options.label: C
options.text: Because our eyes can only see a tiny part of the full spectrum of light

options.label: D
options.text: Because the universe is not visible to the human eye

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the sun and moon in the sky?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that the sun and moon were inanimate objects.

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that the sun and moon were created by humans.

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that the sun and moon were animate beings.

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that the sun and moon were just a reflection of the Earth.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what did Stone Age people believe about the relationship between the spirit and materiality?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that the spirit and materiality were two separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that the spirit and materiality were intertwined.

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that the spirit and materiality were one and the same.

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that the spirit and materiality were unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the movement of insects and plants?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that insects and plants moved by chance.

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that insects and plants moved because of a will within them.

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that insects and plants moved because of the wind.

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that insects and plants moved because of the sun.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the earliest form of religious ritual?

options.label: A
options.text: A form of prayer to the gods.

options.label: B
options.text: A form of sacrifice to the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: An attempt at magic through imitation.

options.label: D
options.text: A form of worship to the gods.

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the world and their place in it?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that the world was a vast and complex place with many mysteries.

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that the world was a simple and straightforward place with no mysteries.

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that they were at the center of the universe and that strangers were less human than they.

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that the world was created by humans and that they were the most important beings.
